question: Question_04_(a)
statement:
Suppose the motion of a spring-mass system is described by the following
differential equation

\[2u'' + 2\gamma u' + 18u = 0, \quad u(0) = 1,\quad u'(0) = -\frac{11}2\]

\textbf{(a)} Find all values of the parameter $\gamma$ for which the
system is overdamped or critically damped (that is the mass cannot pass
its equilibrium position more than once, so there are no oscillatory
solutions).
sols:
Given the equation

\[\displaystyle{}2u'' + 2 \gamma u' + 18 u = 0,\]

we can obtain the characteristic equation by substituting a solution

\[\displaystyle{}u(t)=\exp(rt)\]

and looking at the resulting polynomial. Doing this we get

\[\displaystyle{}2r^2 + 2 \gamma r + 18 = 0\]

which has roots

\begin{align*}
r &= \frac{-2\gamma \pm \sqrt{4 \gamma^2 - 4(2)(18)}}{4} \\
&= -\frac{\gamma}{2} \pm \frac{\sqrt{\gamma^2 - 36}}{2} \\
&= \frac12\left(-\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^2-6^2}\right)
\end{align*}.

Now we study the behaviour of the roots of the equation. Note that
$\gamma > 0$ is necessary for physical damping.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  When $\gamma^2 - 36 < 0$, there are complex roots to the system, and
  there are oscillations. Thus the system is \emph{underdamped}.
\item
  When $\gamma^2 - 36 > 0$, the square root always yields a real value.
  Since $\sqrt{\gamma^2 - 36} < \gamma$ (assuming $\gamma>0$), it
  follows that both roots are negative (so the amplitude decays) and
  real (so there are no oscillations). Thus, the system is
  \emph{overdamped}.
\end{itemize}

Thus, there is overdamping for $\gamma > 6$ and underdamping for
$\gamma < 6$ (and therefore critical damping if $\gamma=6$).
hints:
What are the roots of the characteristic equation as a function of
$\gamma$.
